isis.stitle: DT 466 / DT 570 / HT 570 Service Manual - 2004 Emissions with EGR - Cylinder Head and Valve Train - Reconditioning - Refacing Valves

note.para: If the valves are in serviceable condition, they may be refaced to the specified angles, as required.

caution.para: To avoid engine damage, maintain the minimum valve face margin across the entire valve face. An insufficient valve face margin will not provide proper heat dissipation, ultimately causing the valve to warp or break.

note.para: Make sure that there is sufficient coolant in the valve grinding machine reservoir. Turn coolant pump on before grinding.

step1.para: Use the dressing stud attachment on the grinder to dress the cutting stone.

note.para: Intake valves and exhaust valves have different valve face margins.

step1.para: Install valve in the grinder and set the grinder to the specified angle.

note.para: Removal of too much material may reduce the margin below minimum specifications.

step1.para: Grind the valve face. Only remove the minimum amount of material necessary.
Use a caliper to measure the valve face margin at four locations. If any of the measurements are less than the minimum specification , replace valve.

caution.para: To avoid engine damage, leave a sufficient amount of material so that the valve bridge does not contact the valve retainer keys or valve rotator during operation. Refacing the tip of the valve stem provides a new wear surface for the valve bridge.

step1.para: Use the dressing stud attachment on the grinder to dress the cutting stone.
Install the valve in the grinder so that the tip of the valve stem is close to the grinding stone.
Briefly touch the tip of the valve stem to the grinding stone. Only remove the minimum amount of material that is necessary.

figure.caption: Applying Prussian Blue™ to valve face

step1.para: After refacing a valve, spread a thin film of Prussian Blue™ on the valve face and insert the valve in the valve guide.
Apply pressure on the center of the valve head while turning the valve 90 degrees on the valve seat.

Remove the valve from the cylinder head. Check the impression that was made on the valve seat and valve face. Prussian Blue should appear around the entire contact surface of the valve seat and valve face.

Perform this check several times to rule out any errors. If the Prussian Blue™ contact impression is good, proceed to valve installation. If the Prussian Blue™ contact impression is not good, continue with resurfacing valve seats.
